Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Berg> Cryptopia and the Hush web wallet are two entirely different issues that do not intersect, for those reading along.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Berg> Cryptopia being down is not due to Hush, but due to them. We are working with them to resolve the issue and get them up to speed.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Berg> Unfortunately what should have already been progressed past in a couple of emails has been slowed to a crawl due to Cryptopia's horrendous level of support.... To our community members, feel free to get in their ears as well about getting it together... We are doing all we can on that front, but waiting for correspondence for weeks is no fun and makes progress extremely slow.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Pixelised> Without (shell or otherwise) access to the webserver, I've gone back to the start of the whole process. With the certificate information my web browser provides, the certification provider/issuer "Let's encrypt"  recommends the use of Certbot which if you install, it should automatically renew every 90 days via cron as a cron job. There may have been an issue at the time when cron ran that renew request and now you'll have to wait 90 days for the next run, unless you manually do it...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Pixelised> Yes, I used to be paid professional a web application developer/Linux admin (in the past). I do other work to pay the bills but for now I just delve back into it as a hobby.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Pixelised> @c0prhd, the ssl certificate issue definitely has no relation to what's going on with Cryptopia. They're a third party, a business that runs a cryptocurrency exchange that features Hush amoungst all the other alt-coins. They put their wallet in maintenance well before the certificate expired.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Pixelised> SSL provides encryption security between your computer and the Hush explorer web server. Since you aren't logging in with usernames/passwords or sending sensitive info I wouldn't stress too much for now.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Pixelised i have fought certbot many times, it's never ever worked in a cronjob for me

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] ```# certbot -q renew Attempting to renew cert (wallet.myhush.org) from /etc/letsencrypt/renewal/wallet.myhush.org.conf produced an unexpected error: Failed authorization procedure. wallet.myhush.org (http-01): urn:acme:error:unauthorized :: The client lacks sufficient authorization :: Invalid response from http://wallet.myhush.org/.well-known/acme-challenge/FZ8xZdo3obNTFS9taaH9Nt70SAvCumW0vVR46_3ALhw: "\r\n404 Not Found\r\n\r\n

404 Not Found

\r\n
". Skipping. All renewal attempts failed. The following certs could not be renewed: /etc/letsencrypt/live/wallet.myhush.org/fullchain.pem (failure) 1 renew failure(s), 0 parse failure(s)```

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i finally fixed https://explorer.myhush.org

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> had to reverse engineer some stuff and learned that haproxy + certbot ssl automation does not exist, so it requires a silly human to fix this every few months. I just made it work for now

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> this was some magic that made it work `cat /etc/letsencrypt/archive/explorer.myhush.org/{fullchain,privkey}9.pem > /etc/ssl/explorer.myhush.org/explorer.myhush.org.pem.new
`
